Long-term complications include post-thrombotic syndrome (PTS) and post-embolic pulmonary hypertension (PH).

20-50% of DVTs will become complicated with TPS despite well-managed treatment (5-10% will develop severe TPS)

The risk is particularly high in cases of iliofemoral thrombosis.

The severity of TPS is assessed using the [[Post-thrombotic syndrome 2C-227-DE-A02|Villalta score]].

L''''HTP'''''occurs after severe PE or recurrent PE. It leads to heart failure (left and right) 2C-234-EP-B01|right heart failure ([[Performing and interpreting an electrocardiogram (ecg) SDD-185|SDD: performing and interpreting an electrocardiogram]]).

question.title: What is a long-term complication of VTE (Deep Vein Thrombosis) that is assessed using the Villalta score?

option_a.title: Post-embolic pulmonary hypertension (PH)
option_a.description: A condition that occurs after a pulmonary embolism

option_b.title: Post-thrombotic syndrome (PTS)
option_b.description: A condition that occurs after a deep vein thrombosis

option_c.title: Right heart failure
option_c.description: A condition that occurs when the right side of the heart is not functioning properly

option_d.title: Left heart failure
option_d.description: A condition that occurs when the left side of the heart is not functioning properly

correct_option.title: B
correct_option.description: The letter of the correct option
